greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: An omega analog for a nonstandard factorization based on the sieve of Eratosthenes (A083221).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
Index entries for sequences generated by sieves
program: \\ Assuming A250469 and its inverse A268674 have been precomputed, then the following is reasonably fast:

ordinal_transform(invec) = { my(om = Map(), outvec = vector(length(invec)), pt); for(i=1, length(invec), if(mapisdefined(om,invec[i]), pt = mapget(om, invec[i]), pt = 0); outvec[i] = (1+pt); mapput(om,invec[i],(1+pt))); outvec; };
\\ Or, using also some of the code from above:
A003961(n) = my(f = factor(n)); for (i=1, #f~, f[i, 1] = nextprime(f[i, 1]+1)); factorback(f); \\ From A003961
xref: Cf. A253557 (a similar analog for bigomega), A302050, A302051, A302052, A302039, A302055 (other analogs).
Differs from A302031 for the first time at n=59, where a(59) = 1, while A302031(59) = 2.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Mar 31 2018
